I think Aries has a good point about not being able to fight an emotion or a concept. That's why I see the war on terror as having two different aspects:
 
 1) The neutralization of current terrorist groups and harboring or aiding states. This will usually mean the use of military force to kill or capture, but also disrupting their flow of communications and funding. We can't just look at this as 'let's kill all the terrorists,' because you will never ever be able to. You need to kill or capture the ones you can, and hamper the abilities of the others.
 
 2) Change perception. This aspect is absolutely critical and often overlooked. You can go out and kill 10,000 terrorist fighters, but how many more do you create in doing that? We need to let people see that the US is not the devil incarnate, that we're not evil imperialists. What we essentially need to do is change the way these people think, especially the younger generations. All they have now are radical clerics and state-run propoganda, and they don't have access to any other point of view. I think that the key to this step is free media in the Middle East. Al-Jazeera, while pretty biased, is laying the groundwork for this. It's also why it is so imperative that we succeed in Iraq and win the hearts and minds of the people, so they would have good opinions of Americans, and these ideas would slowly begin to spread throughout the region.
 
 The problem we often have is a balance between the two of these aspects.

I can't think of ever hearing that kind of talk with their kids around, and even if it does at times happen, there is a difference between that and the systematic, institutionalized teaching of hatred mentioned above. 
 
 You may be referring to gripes that are sometimes heard--of course more common than what I was referring to above--but I see no hatred in these comments whatsoever. 
 
 America has devoted enormous resources to systematically rid its citizens of those kinds of feelings; I cannot say the same for the Muslim world--it is an error to attempt to equalize the U.S. and these countries on this matter.

As a US citizen, I was pointing out that the root causes of our war on terrorism should be examined and our public attitude. By assuming retaliation against us is due to Islamic extremists just disliking the US as an entity is naive. Why are we declaring a war on terror and what created that war? To win any war the goals of an enemy must be defeated. Our last war was declared on the basis of non-existant WMDs and fully supported by a gullible public. The war on terror is based on equally shaky ground, our foreign policy, and not winable in the conventional sense we view as winning. In response to the topic title, no, we're not winning the war on terror.
